Now the German Chancellor has summed up many of the factors that led to it in a snappy video. She said the UK had enjoyed a patchy relationship with the EU, opting out of the Schengen zone and the Euro. They have always said: we are an island, we want more independence. Many of the thousands who shared the video say this was just a statement of fact. But not Tory MP Johnny Mercer. The Brexiteer tweeted the video with the pithy reply: Jeez. Bye.   That triggered an onslaught of comments to the Plymouth Moor View MP - some positive, and some very negative. Winston Churchills hashtag-loving grandson, the Tory MP Nicholas Soames, wrote: #anabsolutelyhistoricallydisastrousdecisionbyourwonderfulcountry. Allie Renison, head of Europe and Trade policy at the Institute of Directors, wrote: Um, this is literally many Leavers arguments rationale for the UK leaving...not a criticism at all. Just is what it is, what many say in the UK when people ask whats behind our slightly detached relationship  eventual decision to leave. I think shes just speaking about the context.   Another Twitter user wrote: Merkel’s comments seem pretty reasonable to me ... what am I missing  But Brexiteers also piled in to agree with Mr Mercer. One wrote: Translation: The UK never gave up full control of its borders and currency, and for that reason we dont like them. Perhaps Mr Mercer didnt get to the bit later in the video when Ms Merkel talked about the relationship shed like to see with the UK. After Brexit, she said, we and Britain orce in a good process and work closely on defence, counter-terrorism, security, policing, trade and research projects. Ms Merkel made the comments during the signing of a French-German friendship treaty with Emmanuel Macron yesterday.  She said: The relationship of Great Britain to Europe was always very patchy. They abstained from many of the policies. They are not in the euro zone, they are not part of the free travel area, they dont take part in domestic policies. They have always said: we are an island, we want more independence. For them Europe was always about, or mainly about the free trade of goods and they didnt really value us deepening our relationship.

title: brexit michel barnier crushes key
story: NewsBrexit: Michel Barnier crushes key plan B allies hoped could save Theresa MayThe EU has repeatedly ruled out putting an expiry date on the backstopShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JAN News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMichel Barnier has crushed a key plan B allies of Theresa May had hoped could have led to a breakthrough on her rejected Brexit deal.The EU has repeatedly ruled out putting an expiry date on the backstop - an insurance policy to keep an open border on the island of Ireland in the event of no deal.The EUs Chief Negotiator said that calls for a time-limit had been repeatedly discussed and rejected by the EU.Mr Barnier said in a joint interview to European newspapers “we cannot tie the backstop to a time limit”. Government loyalist Andrew Murrison tabled an amendment to Theresa Mays Withdrawal Bill to set an expiry date on the Northern Ireland backstop.   The amendment was not chosen by the Speaker and the PMs deal was rejected by  votes.On Monday Theresa May ed to the Commons to put forward her plan B - which involves minor tweaks to her first plan.MPs are now putting forward amendments to try and seize control of the process.Mr Murrison believes his amendment, which imposes a time-limit on the backstop, could help Mrs May get her deal through the Commons by appealing to moderate MPs who just want Brexit sorted. But Mr Barnier has insisted there can be no time limit on the backstop.He told them: The backstop is like an insurance. It is not there to be used. Andso, only provisionally. However, we cannot tie the backstop to a time limit.   Asked why not, he told journalists: Imagineyour home’s insurance was limited to five years and you’d have a problem after six years... Thats dficult to justy, he replied. Its similar with the backstop. That is why it is tied to an event: as soon as there is an agreement between the EU and the UK that makes an internal border unnecessary, it will be obsolete. Let me remind you that we have negotiated the elements of the backstop with the British government and have integrated their wishes into it. On Tuesday the EU insisted that a no deal Brexit would mean a hard border on the island of Ireland.At a press conference the chief spokesman for European commission president Jean-Claude Juncker, said it was “pretty obvious” border infrastructure would be necessarythere was no agreement.   But on Wednesday they backtracked. The same spokesman said: The EU is determined to do all it can - deal or no deal- to avoid a hard border in Ireland. Meanwhile the chief commissioner of the Irish Human Rights and Equality Commissionsaid the Withdrawal Agreement reached between the UK and the EU left signicant gaps in the protection of human rights. Emily Logan said: I dont think the public understand that the implications... people might find themselves in a situation of being forced to assume an identy they wouldnt choose. Ms Logan said the offer of continued EU citizenship should be extended to all the people of NorthernIreland as defined by the Good Friday Agreement, given recognition of the birthright of people in NorthernIrelandto identy as Irish or British, or both. The last situation we wish to see is one where the people of NorthernIrelandfeel forced to choose their identity based on what they think their post-Brexit entitlements might be, she said.

story: NewsMan wins seat for le in Parliament thanks to his ancestor becoming a Lord in Aeneas Simon Mackay, a Tory investment banker, can now vote on your laws and claim £ a day for leShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN NewsAeneas Simon Mackay, a Tory investment banker, can now vote on your laws and claim £ a day for le "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man has joined the House of Lords for le after an election he could only enter because his great-grandads cousins dads fourth cousins dads cousins great-great-great-grandad was made a Lord in . Tory investment banker Aeneas Simon Mackay, the th Lord Reay, can now vote on your laws and claim pound a day after triumphing in a hereditary peer by-election - a system branded a mockery of our democracy. The -year-old is the chief of ancient Scottish Clan Mackay, whose leader Donald Mackay was handed a peerage by Charles I. According to the Clan Mackay Society, folklore describes Lord Reay as a magician who won a work-loving gang of fairies in an encounter with a witch in a cave.His coat of arms is said to be two daggers pointed at a roebucks head surrounded by the heads of three muzzle-wearing bears.   But the th Lords existence has been a bit less mystical. He went to pound,-a-year Westminster School before founding a corporate finance advisory boutique and working in New York. His father, the th Lord, sat in the Lords for almost  years and campaigned against onshore wind farms before his death in . According to Cracrofts Peerage, Donald Mackay was the current Lords great-grandads cousins dads fourth cousins dads cousins great-great-great-grandad. Darren Hughes, chief executive of the Electoral Reform Society, said: While MPs debate what taking back control really means, Lords have picked yet another aristocrat to vote on our laws for le. With just -odd votes from Britains feudal few, this man will now be able to claim pound a day plus travel costs to steer our politics.  Labour leader in the Lords Baroness Smith added: As much as we welcome an inidual Lord, the system has had its day. It is increasingly dficult to defend - a temporary measure that has gone on beyond its time. Todays election result was a hangover from Tony Blairs bid to modernise the House of Lords. Hereditary peers were mostly cast out in  but  remained as a compromise. That means when one dies or retires, there is an election to find their replacement. But only hereditary peers can stand in that election, and only members of the House of Lords can vote. The latest election was held to replace Tory Lord Skelmersdale, an Old Etonian who sat in the Lords for  years before his death in October.  All  candidates were men including  Conservatives, five independent crossbenchers and one unaffiliated. In total  peers voted and Lord Reay won with  votes, beating the second-placed Earl of Leicester who won . The Earl of Carnarvon, who lives in the real-le home that stages Downton Abbey, won just  votes. In his manesto, Lord Reay told peers: My career expertise derives from  years in the financial services sector in London and New York, at investment banks and boutique corporate firms , with a focus on advising UK and international businesses. I am a board member of three technology companies. Based predominantly in London and partially in rural Lancashire, I will be able to devote as much time to the House as required. The Mirror has contacted the peer for comment.

story: NewsBurglar claimed he moved into home after popstar Cheryl donated it to himAndrew Coates, , appeared on several hours of CCTV footage with a rucksack and sleeping bag inside the Devon home of Alison Piper, a jury heardShareByStuart AbelAbigail OLeary:,  JAN NewsAppearing at Plymouth Crown Court, Coates denied burgling the property in March last year "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn alleged burglar caught inside a house claimed he had moved into the property after it was donated to him by popstar Cheryl, a court heard. Andrew Coates, , appeared on several hours of CCTV footage with a rucksack and sleeping bag inside the Devon home of Alison Piper, a jury heard. When questioned by police, Coates said the former Girls Aloud singer and X Factor judge had gted him the home after buying it for pound.m the day before. It is alleged that Coates stole several valuable items from the house, including a Rolex watch worth more than pound,. Appearing at Plymouth Crown Court, Coates denied burgling the property in March last year, alongside one charge of criminal damage and three theft charges. Alison Piper, the home’s true owner, told the trial that she had not sold the house to the celebrity, whose maiden name is Cheryl Tweedy.  Adrian Chaplin, opening the case for the Crown Prosecution Service, said Coates was arrested after the residents ed to their home in the morning. He said: “Mr Coates said that he had been given the house, which had been bought the previous day by Cheryl Tweedy. He had been given it by her during a conversation.” Mr Chaplin added that Coates had later been diagnosed by psychiatrists as suffering from delusional disorder. The barrister said that the defendant believed that everything in the house were “gts” for him from the former X Factor judge. Mr Chaplin told the jury that Coates appeared on several hours of CCTV footage from the couple’s home security cameras after arriving at .pm. The barrister continued that he was carrying a rucksack and a sleeping bag. Coates allegedly stole the home owners Rolex Yacht Master, Apple Watch and ious keys.  He added he was spotted in a detached garage inside a white Ferrari and appeared to be looking for the keys. Mr Chaplin said that Coates was later picked up inside the home in just a shirt and boxer shorts. He added that the defendant took a shower but left the water running and flooded the bathroom, causing damage to the furnishings. Mrs Piper told the jury that she ed home moments before her husband in separate cars at am the next morning. She added that she asked the defendant who he was but he replied by asking her the same question. She said: “He made me feel very uncomfortable ashe resented my presence there. He made me feel asI was intruding. “He took a step towards me and he stared at me very aggressively and assertively.” Barry White, for Coates, asked her what she thought of the suggestion that she had sold the house to Cheryl Tweedy. Mrs Piper said: “No, I did not.” The trial continues.

story: NewsChippy unveils spiciest fish and chips in the world that you need waiver to eatMillers Fish and Chips, in Haxby near York, is selling a flaming hot fillet of fish coated in a blazing batterShareCommentsByBarnaby Kellaway:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video chippy-unleashes-spiciest-fish-chips-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family-run chippy is blowing the taste buds off its customers who have to sign a WAIVER before eating what they claim is the worlds spiciest fish and chips. The flaming hot fillet of fish is coated in a blazing batter made from ten heat-packed ingredients and then doused in chillies and hot sauce. The fiery concoction is the brainchild of father and son team Nick and David Miller, owners of Millers Fish and Chips, which has been running since . Nick, , and David, , have been developing the recipe for a month and tried it out on staff members and loyal customers before adding it to the menu on Tuesday.   Brave diners will be charged pound. for a standard sized portion and have to sign a document before tucking in, so Millers arent held responsible for its effects. Millers, in Haxby, outside York, North Yorks, was named best fish and chip shop in the UK at the  National Fish  Chip Awards. Nick said: Its important to offer something a bit dferent now and again. We’ve ended up with a battered fillet which tastes incredible but is ridiculously spicy. Im slightly scared to see what happens once customers start ordering it. Weve already tried it out with a few customers who said they were lovers of spicy food and they were blown away by the heat.   Anyone who orders will have to sign a piece of paper to say they dont hold us responsible for what might happen when they take a bite. Despite being incredibly spicy, the flavours are actually really nice so Im hoping some people might actually enjoy it. The recipe is made up of ten heat-packed ingredients including chilli powder, dried chillis, cayenne pepper, paprika, chilli flakes and hot sauce. Also included is a smattering of Seabrook Fire Eaters Scorchin Hot Trinidad Scorpion Chilli Crisps, which are said to be the spiciest on the market. David, whos dad set Millers up during the Second World War, said: This isnt quite traditional but I think its important to move with the times. Its exciting to try out new things and dferent recipes.  I think what weve come up with is actually delicious, as long as you like a bit of spice. Marcus Coleman, CEO of Seafish who run the National Fish and Chip Awards, said: “Nick, David and the team at Millers are always challenging the norm when it comes to delicious fish and chips. Since they were crowned the UK’s best fish and chip shop in , they’ve helped to break the mould of what people expect when they walk through the door.

story: NewsCouple shared perfect evening on dream holiday before it ended in tragedyAndrew Samuel watched the sunset with Natalie Morris on the Indonesian island of Lembongan but he woke to found she had drownedShareCommentsByMegan Adams:,  JAN NewsNatalie Morris, , died while on holiday in Bali with her partner Andrew "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA boyfriend had the most perfect evening with his girlfriend on their dream trip to Indonesia - then woke up to find her drowned in a swimming pool, an inquest heard. Andrew Samuel, , watched the sunset with Natalie Morris, , after travelling to the idyllic island of Lembongan. The hearing was told it was the couples first night on the small Indonesian island and they had been on a moped, gone for a meal and ed to their villa to watch DVDs. The couple had been sipping Bombay Sapphire gin and tonics by their small private pool after getting back at around .pm. Andrew said: It was literally one of the most perfect evenings that you could have had. It was just really nice. We got to the island and it was such a picturesque island.  Andrew said the couple had watched the sunset and discussed plans on what to do for Natalies th birthday. He said: We were making plans for the future. It was such a nice day there was nothing sad about it at all. The inquest heard Andrew went to bed around midnight but Natalie decided to stay up to finish her drink and have a cigarette. But Andrew woke up at .am to discover his girlfriend had not come to bed and he rushed outside. The inquest heard Natalie was discovered face down in the pool of the Secret Outlook villa and desperate Andrew ed in to save her and carried out CPR.   Emergency services were called but Natalie was pronounced dead on September  last year. The inquest heard there was a partly smoked cigarette and a lighter about a foot from the edge of the pool. Andrew said: My hypothesis of what happened is that I think Nat had been having a cigarette. I think she was probably, knowing her, having a dance and I assume she must have been on the side of the pool. I believe that she must have slipped, hit her head on the side of the pool and unfortunately rolled the wrong way. Because she was tall enough to stand up in the pool. If she was not unconscious she would have been able to stand up. From where the cigarette was it looked like she would have fallen and dropped it.   The inquest heard the couple had been sitting on decking that was about six foot from the pool. There was outdoor lighting and the private pool and garden were securely locked with a ten foot wall surrounding it. Andrew said they were onlytipsy after enjoying a few drinks and he heard nothing after going to bed. He added: If there was a shout I think I would have heard it. The inquest heard the couple had only just decided to go to Lembongan after a typhoon had changed their original plans. A post mortem examination in Bali found no external injuries. Her cause of death was given as drowning. The inquest heard there was alcohol found in Natalies system and internal bruising was found to the left side of the front of the head. Natalie, originally of Merthyr, South Wales, had been dating Andrew for four years and the couple lived in Cardf Bay. She was an executive assistant at Travis Perkins builders yard.   Sister Janine Lloyd said in a statement: Natalie and Andrew brought out the best in each other and were as close as any couple could be. She was really at her peak before the time of her untimely death. Natalie was a light that shone so brightly it seemed impossible that it would go out. Coroner Andrew Barkley ed a narrative conclusion at the inquest in Pontypridd. He said: The evidence doesnt tell us how she got into the pool and neither does it tell us why she couldnt extract herself from the pool. Recording his conclusion, Mr Barkley said: Natalie Morris died from the effects of drowning in circumstances which are unclear. The evidence does not reveal how she entered the water.

title: king bling fugitive who taunted
story: NewsKing of Bling fugitive who taunted police with celeb selfies in Dubai is jailedAdam Ali, , was extradited back to the UK and sentenced to more than three years after being convicted in his absenceShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAdam Ali appeared to be living a luxurious le in Dubai - he posted this image on Instagram "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA fugitive branded the King of Bling who taunted police on social media has been jailed after being extradited back to the UK. Adam Ali shared photos of himself in Dubai after fleeing the country, despite having been charged over allegations of dangerous driving. In the images, he could be seen partying with celebs Anthony Joshua and Gordon Ramsay, apparently showing little remorse for his actions.There is no indication that either celebrity knew of the -year-olds criminality when they posed for photographs with him. Ali taunted police through his Instagram feed by regularly sharing images of himself in clubs and driving sports cars. He appeared to be living a lavish lestyle.  But the partygoer, from Thornwood, Epping, has now been extradited from the United Arab Emiratesand appeared at Southwark Crown Court yesterday. Ali had previously been sentenced to three years imprisonment after being convicted - in his absence - of possession of ammunition and dangerous driving. And he was sentenced to an additional  months imprisonment for his failure to surrender to the court. This sentence will run concurrently. Ali was arrested and charged on January ,  ,after officers went to his home in Epping in relation to allegations of dangerous driving. During a search of his house ammunition was discovered.   After being bailed toto court later in January , Ali fled to Dubai on the first day of his trial. He was found guilty in his absence and was sentenced at Southwark Crown Court on  October  to three years imprisonment. Officers established that Ali was somewhere in Dubai, where he appeared to lead a very lavish and luxurious lestyle. In September , police were alerted through information published on his account that Ali had made a trip to the USA. With some investigation, it was deemed that he made this trip under an alias, Adam Khala. Through the joint collaboration between Dubai Police, Dubai Public Prosecutors, Interpol, the National Crime Agency and the Met, Ali was identied coming back into the UAE and was arrested at the airport by UAE authorities on  November . The extradition process then began.  Met officers travelled to Dubai on  January and Ali was extradited back to the UK on  January. Upon hisAli was held in a west London police station before his appearance in court yesterday. Detective Sergeant Andy Swindells, of the Westminster Crime Squad, which investigated this case from the beginning, said: It is satisfying to know that Ali is now where he belongs and will rightly serve time in prison for his crimes. A lot of time and police work has gone into securing this result and I would like to thank the NCA and our international colleagues who were integral to this success. We will do everything in our power to bring to justice those who attempt to evade us. Ian Cruxton, head of International Operations at the NCA, said: Ali fled justice to live a lavish lestyle somewhere he thought his crimes wouldnt catch up with him. Our international partners - especially the Dubai Police and prosecutors - were crucial in helping to catch andhim. It doesnt matter where fugitives run to we will do everything possible to find them.

story: NewsMum drops nine stone and  dress sizes thanks to diet of microwave ready mealsKelley Robinson controlled her weight by consuming ready meals that contained between  and  caloriesShareCommentsByNeil ShawTfany Lo:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsShe started eating ready meals, which were typically between  and  calories a meal "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young mum has revealed her secret of successfully losing  stone - by eating READY MEALS. Kelley Robinson, , put on eight stone - weighing st at a size  - since she gave birth to her son Kylo. She began to feel her knee buckling under the pressure of her enormous frame until she started taking diet pills. But she found that combined with working out, she could actually control her calorie intake much more effectively with the microwave meals. She now weighs a healthy st for her  frame and is a comfy dress size , Cornwall Live reports.  Her chest and cup size also slimmed down - from a F to a more proportionate E. Kelley said: The ready meals made it so easy for me to keep track of exactly what I was consuming calorie wise. They were quick and easy too. It may not sound healthy but I chose low cal ones and it really helped me get started on my weight loss journey. it has got to the point now where people dont actually recognise me on the street. An old friend of mine did a double take the other day when I said hi as she didnt notice it was me at all. My whole outlook on le is dferent. Before all I did was sit about on the sofa and order takeaways whereas now Im super active and have tonnes of energy all the time.  Kelleywas a size  before having Kylo, now three, but after he was born she developed unhealthy eating habits. She typically has white toast for breakfast, followed by sandwich and crisps for lunch, a takeaway for dinner, while snacking on more crisps, fizzy drinks and chocolate. She piled on eight stone, but soon got fed up, and when she got desperate she tried diet pills. They were dreadful, I had no energy and couldnt stop pooing the whole time, she admitted. It was around this time that her fitness fanatic fianceacute, Ryan Lake, stepped in to help. She said: Ryan was amazing, he could see how depressed I was and just gently took control but by coaxing me to the gym. Id never have had the confidence to do it without him. At first I found it so hard, I wanted to give up, I really hated it but I kept at it and with the changes in my diet too I found that I was actually losing weight! She also started eating ready meals, which were typically between  and  calories a meal. Her favourites were Morrison’s Chicken Tikka Masala, Beef Hot Pots or Macaroni, and she started eating Weetabix and fruit for breakfast, with wraps for lunch. The new mum stopped snacking between meals and started swapping sweet drinks for water.  In the first three months of her new regime she lost a whopping three stone. Kelleysaid: It was after that when I got really strict with myself because I realised that I actually I could do it. I cut out carbs, dairy and even quit the ready meals eventually. In a year Kelley had lost NINE stone. She admitted: Im such a gym bunny now its unreal I go whenever I have a second and absolutely love it. I even get up super early before the kids wake up to go and workout for an hour. I go at least six times a week and make sure to do a mix of cardio and weights. Doing the weights have meant that the saggy skin has really toned up, which is one thing I was worried about losing quite so much. Dedicated Keeley, who is also mother to -year-old Tamzin, has noticed far more than just weight loss benefits from her new regime. Her knees are no longer a problem and her down days are well behind her. The mum-of-two said: I was quite low before as I felt so under-confident but these days I really do feel like a new person. One thing I know is that I couldnt have done it without the support of my amazing family, especially Ryan, who loved me whatever size I was but always wanted the best for me.

title: mum two 20 left without
story: NewsMum-of-two, , left without heat or water for four days in sub-zero temperaturesShannon Avison and her two young sons, from Grimsby, had to share a bed and use an electric blanket to stay warm despite desperate calls to estate agents Ashton EstatesShareCommentsByAbigail OLearyConnor Lynch:,  JAN NewsShannon Avison had to sleep with her two sons on an electric blanket "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mother-of-two was left without heating for days in biting sub-zero temperatures.Shannon Avison, , had no heating or hot water from Friday until yesterday and was forced to sleep in a bed with her two children on top of an electric blanket.The mum, from Grimsby, claimed she made a number of desperate calls to estate agents, Ashton Estates, asking them to fix the boiler.She says they told her they would send someone the same day - but was then left four days in freezing cold temperatures. Her parents had tried to get in contact with the estate agent over the weekend and Shannon said she was told a plumber would finally be round on Monday. As a result of having no heating or hot water, the mother said she was forced to go round to her parents house in order to wash her sons, two-year-old Azaan and nine-month old Sahil.   She also said she was forced to sleep three in a bed for four nights, while using an electric blanket in order to stay warm, because every room in the house was freezing. Shannon said: On Friday the boiler in my house started leaking and producing a strange burning smell, before it stopped working. I immediately rang Ashton Estates to ask them to come round and fix the boiler, as I have two very young sons who I cannot keep in a freezing house, and they told me that a plumber would be round to fix it. Come pm nobody had arrived, so I began to ring the emergency number. I tried numerous times to get through but was unable and eventually the phone itself was turned off.   Over the weekend I tried to ring them again, and so did my parents, with us leaving a lot of voicemails asking them to come and fix the boiler. However nobody got back to us at all. We were then told that a plumber would be round on Monday, but still nobody showed up. Because of this I was forced to look after my children in a freezing house, and the only source of heat that we had was a broken radiator that probably isnt safe and an electric blanket. It takes the radiator about five hours to heat a room and both items use a lot of electricity. My children had to wash at my parents house. I just wanted someone to come round and fix our boiler, I have two infant sons and they shouldnt have to live like this.   A spokesperson from Ashton Estates said a plumber visited the property on Tuesday and managed to get the boiler working again but said the reason it had not been working was due to no gas being on the meter, a claim refuted by Shannon. Ashton Estates said: Our plumbers are very busy but managed to get round earlier today and the gas is now back on. We found the issue to be that there was no gas on the meter, although the plumber did not actually look at the meter itself. They have said that a notication on the boiler indicated to them that there was no gas. Shannon said she did have gas in the meter for the whole weekend, and that the plumber had told her that there was an issue with steam in the boiler and that was what caused it to break.

title: terrifying catalogue knives seized london
story: NewsTerrying catalogue of all the knives seized from capitals streets THIS yearImages lay bare the sheer number of knives taken off the streets by Scotland Yard officers in just a fortnightShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsPolice in Bromley, southeast London, seized a terrying weapon recently "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChilling photos lay bare the sheer number of knives police have taken off the capitals streets already this year. Scotland Yard continues to tackle the horric kne crime epidemic which plagued London, and other large cities, in . And in just two weeks, the force has seized a shocking number of weapons - including a machete and a hunting kne. It has tweeted almost  pictures of the confiscated knives, used in robberies, left in bushes and gathered in stop and searches. One terrying image, shared by the politan Police, shows a crook’s attempt to conceal a razor-sharp kne in a plastic shopping bag. Officers also discovered a discarded weapon lying by a walkway on an estate in Tottenham, north London.  Meanwhile, a machete, at least  inches long, was recovered following a moped chase in Catford, southeast London. Other large blades were seized from children as young as  over a two-week period. In one incident in Camden, north London, three knives were taken from the same thug after he decided to use a meat cleaver as a weapon.  And a sickening picture tweeted by police in Islington shows a -inch sword a suspect was allegedly carrying along with several bags of cannabis. Affluent areas like Notting Hill and Highgate - home to celebrities including Kate Moss and Jude Law - arent free from those who choose to carry blades either. One was unearthed on a Highgate street, while officers attending a disturbance in upper-class Notting Hill allegedly took a kitchen kne, baseball bat and a rolling pin from a group of three men.  And according to Kensington and Cha Police’s Twitter account, a Batman-shaped knuckle duster was discovered on an estate during a stop and search for driving offences. Last year was one of the worst in recent years for murders in London. Figures show the number of people killed hit a -year high with more than a fth of victims teenagers or children. The  homicides recorded by the politan Police included  where the victims were aged  or under. Of those,  were stabbed, five were shot and one woman was killed by a head injury. It was London’s highest homicide total since , which saw  people killed, and a  per cent rise year-on-year. politan Police Commissioner Cressida Dick had recently named street violence as her number one priority and acknowledged that  was challenging.  Kne crime campaigners have welcomed the ongoing work to remove weapons and praised police for putting the images on their Twitter accounts. Patrick Green, of the charity Ben Kinsella Trust, said: It’s really important to take knives off the streets. Some of the work the politan Police have been doing extends beyond stop and search - we know that they are now doing sweeps of parks and public areas. That’s really an important piece of work for us because we know that habitual kne carriers who are fearful of being stopped will place knives in locations so they can go to that location and retrieve them so the work being done by the police there is really welcomed. We have also seen that they are doing a lot of those searches in conjunction with members of the public or community groups so there is a sense of helping other members of the community support to them in their work.  That’s good because local people have a lot of intelligence about where things might be hidden. Targeted use of stop and search done in an intelligence led way we are happy with - it’s an important police tactic. We are really pleased to see the police take a proactive stance however as good as the measures the police take are, they will not on their own solve the kne crime problem. Part of the issue we have got to address is the step before someone carries a kne. Preventative work and early intervention is as important as everything the police do. Dr Mark Prince runs the The Kiyan Prince Foundation, which works with young people to end violence. His son Kiyan, , was stabbed to death on May , , receiving a single lethal kne wound as he intervened to stop the bullying of another teen.   Dr Prince said: Work like this does make a dference because every area has to be responsible for the part that they play and for enforcing the law. You could have been on the way to using that kne and because you’ve been caught you’ve saved a le, so there is sense behind the enforcement and we need that. It’s collective - everybody needs to be doing their part. MP Stephen Timms, who was stabbed at one of his constituency surgeries in May , added: I’m pleased the Met is putting so much emphasis on confiscating knives. But we also need to stop people getting them in the first place. That means tackling the online s which supply them.

title: traumatised mum reveals how baby
story: NewsTraumatised mum reveals how baby girl nearly died after relative kissed her lipsKaylah Merritt, who is just one year old, spent four days in hospital after being kissed by a family member with a cold soreShareCommentsByAliki KraterouJasmine Kazlauskas:,  JAN NewsKaylah Merritt is lucky to be alive after being taken ill with Eczema Herpeticum "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA traumatised mum has described how her baby daughter nearly died - after becoming ill when a family member kissed her lips. Kaylah Merritt, who is just one year old, was hospitalised for four days last month after a relative kissed her on the lips while they had a cold sore. She soon developed an awful purple rash all over her body and was left crying in pain. Her parents Brogan Thomas and Connor Merritt, both , rushed her to Darlington Memorial Hospital for emergency treatment.  Kaylah, from Staindrop, Darlington, County Durham, was diagnosed with Eczema Herpeticum, a viral infection caused by the herpes virus, and needed two rounds of antibiotics and several dferent creams to soothe her skin.Her parents are now urging adults to be aware of the risks kissing a baby on the mouth can bring after doctors said the tots experience could have been fatal.Stay-at-home mum-of-one Brogan said: Kaylah was crying so hard, I knew it could only mean she was in pain. We were at home and I was about to put her in the bath when I suddenly saw all the marks on her legs.It was an awful nightmare, there were purple rashes everywhere and Kaylah was sobbing her heart out.Eczema herpeticum is an infection usually caused by the herpes simplex  virus, which is usually responsible for the appearance of cold sores on the mouth or other parts of the body.People with atopic dermatitis and other skin diseases are more prone to getting infected, and the condition is more common among infants and young children.Symptoms include blisters, high fever and swollen lymph glands and can be proven deadly in some cases.   I was terried, my first thought was it had something to do with meningitis because she had it before.My fiance was petried, but he kept me calm and made sure Kaylah was calm too.I instantly knew we had to take her to the hospital.The doctors told us that someone with a cold sore must have kissed her on the lips and because babies immune systems are not strong enough, she developed the rash.When the doctors told me how dangerous it was I cried and cried thinking how I could have lost her due to a silly kiss.Connor was shocked and couldnt believe all this was down to a kiss too.If we hadnt gone to the hospital quickly, it could have been very dangerous, we could have lost her.I was so relieved when Kaylah was out of danger.Kaylah previously survived meningitis and needed a lumbar puncture to survive.This time, doctors told her parents the Eczema Herpeticum could have been very dangerous so it was lucky she was brought into hospital when she was.Kaylah was able to go back home after four days on a ward but her parents said she still hasnt fully recovered. Even a month later, she still needs to take daily medication until the virus is gone and must attend doctors appointments on a weekly basis.Brogan said: I am over the moon Kaylahs home now and enjoying herself with her toys and extra cuddles.I just want other parents to know, you dont have to be a physically ill to harm a baby - you can just be a carrier of the virus and still affect them.

story: NewsTravelodge digger driver pictured for first time as family reveal his real battleJohn Manley, , is now being treated for mental health issues after allegedly ploughing the construction vehicle into a newly built branch of the budget hotel in LiverpoolShareCommentsByJonathan HumphriesDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsJohn Manley, , who is being treated in hospital for mental health issues "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the first picture of the digger driver who crashed into a Travelodge hotel in a rampage. John Manley, , is nowbeing treatedfor mental health issues after allegedly ploughing the construction vehicle into a newly built Travelodge branch of the budget hotel over unpaid wages. Footage of the incident, which left the hotel front in Edge Lane destroyed, went viral after being filmed by other workers on the site. The rampage appeared to have been triggered after Mr Manleys pound wages were allegedly not paid on time by sub-contracting firm MF Constructions. Yesterday his cousin, Jason Pellegrini, , revealed Mr Manley had been seeking mental health treatment for a number of weeks.Today, his cousin reiterated that rumours circulating claiming the driver had actually been paid but had not checked his bank balance were .  In a new statement to the Liverpool Echo, Mr Pellegrini said: I would just like to stress what I stated in my local paper and clear something up.John Manley did not get paid on Monday, I know this as he does not have a bank account as he did not have the necessary identication, his wages, when paid, go into a family members account. This was checked on Monday and there was pound donated by a friend.If, as has been reported, there was an alleged glitch in the system, why would the boss refuse to answer any calls or messages which John left   Should he not explain this to his workers who break their back in a physically demanding job and just want a honest wage  We would like to highlight the fact again we do not condone Johns actions for the simple fact someone could have been seriously injured or worse pay disputes can be handled in dferent ways. Potentiallythe unions had more power it could be resolved that way, however I doubt that will happen whilst we have the muppets in charge of our country. His cousin yesterday said the huge strain on mental health services in the local area meant Mr Manley failed to receive adequate help.  Mr Pellegrini said: Hes had a very, very bad le. Hes not an angel we dont want to portray him as an angel... We have been trying to get him help but theres such a long waiting list. Its not down to the health care professionals but its a lack of resources. We are not condoning what he did at all someone could have been seriously hurt and hes not a national hero like some people have been making out. He is very troubled and its something when he has had to do what he did to get the kind of help he needs. He told me he does not want any money, he just wants his mates to get paid and he wants to get well.  He added that Mr Manley had traumatic childhood and only worked sporadically. It was claimed that Mr Manley was sleeping on a relatives couch inMerseyside in the lead up to the incident and was desperate after his employer MF Construction, allegedly failed to pay his pound wages. Mr Pellegrini said: He would ring the GP at am when it opens, and there would already be  people in the waiting line for an appointment. We wanted to get him a to a psychiatrist in Crosby but the waiting list is so long. I know he was technically of no fixed abode and could not claim benefits, so when he didnt work he literally had nothing. He had no money for gas, electric or food. According to Mr Pellegrinis account, neither his boss or his employer would answer the phone. I think in the end he just snapped. He said to me he would not have done ithed had an explanation.  Triton Construction, the main contractor for the Travelodge site, revealed there was no structural damage to the site. Michael Parkinson, managing director of Triton, said: It is our understanding that one of the labourers working for MF Construction, who were employed as the groundworks contractor for the project, had been waiting for his boss to arrive with his wages, which he told other workers on site were overdue. It is alleged that the labourer couldn’t track down the owner of MF Construction and he became increasingly frustrated. At approximately .pm the labourer took it upon himself to drive a small mini excavator through the entrance screen of the hotel and subsequently caused damage to finishes within the reception. The labourer then ran from the scene and to our knowledge is being pursued by the police. Fortunately there appears to be no structural damage so repairs can be undertaken relatively quickly. “ Merseyside Police confirmed they located a man as part of the investigation into the incident, but stated he is not under arrest.

story: NewsIncredible photos show mum giving birth in outdoor bathtub without medical helpWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGES: Hannah Taylor gave birth to her son Koa in an "incredible, blissful, experience" with just her husband Tyler and no-one telling her to pushShareCommentsByPatricia MurphyChris kitching:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video meet-woman-who-gave-birth-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThese are the incredible photos of a first-time mum giving birth in an outdoor bath tub after choosing to forego medical help during the delivery. Hannah Taylor grew up with “scary” stories about childbirth from her own mum and wanted a serene experience for her son Koa. The -year-old yoga teacher decided the best option for her and her son - now aged three months - was a freebirth without a medical attendant or professional present. Hannah and her partner Tyler Couchman welcomed lb oz baby Koa in an outdoor bath with no-one telling her to push, describing it as an incredible, blissful, experience. Just Tyler and best friend Shea Zamarra were in attendance. Hannah, from the US city of Sacramento, Calornia, said: “My mum had traumatic births with me and my sister and it didn’t sit well with me. “Growing up I had only heard scary stories of birth and when I heard about my friend’s experience with unassisted birth. It felt right to me.  “A unassisted birth is one without medical intervention. You give birth unhindered and without medical interference.“No one telling you when to push, you just completely listen to your own body. “During my pregnancy I did a lot of research and I read a lot of books. I listened to podcasts focused on women and their unassisted birthing stories.  She added: “I went into labour in early morning at about am on October  and my active contractions started around .am. “I was just home with my partner and my best friend Shea. I hadn’t planned to move to the outside to the tub, I just wanted to use it as somewhere to take a break during labour. “I was on the floor of my room when I decided to move outside to the tub. It is connected to the warm water mains from our house.  “It was an incredible, blissful, experience and I was ecstatic. Meeting my little boy for the first time was incredible.” Hannah and her sister, Jessica Taylor, were born by Caesarean section which left her keen to explore other options during her own pregnancy. Unassisted birth is the process of having a baby without the presence of a medical attendant or professional, which Hannah believed was the best option for her family. Hannahs partner Tyler, , a chef, added: So far it was the most amazing experience of my le. I had never heard of free birth before, but catching my son in my arms was the most amazing thing. Holding him brought tears to my eyes. It felt like a dream.  While Hannah’s birth was unassisted, the mum did attend regular prenatal appointments with a midwe to make sure her pregnancy was healthy. Hannah said she would have rethought her plans had there been a health issue or potential danger for Koa. She said: “I had a healthy pregnancy and I visited a midwe all along. I had prenatal care. “There was no sign that anything was wrong, andthere had been I would have had to think about changing my plan.  “Depending on the severity I would have had to consider a hospital birth in that case. But I really made sure I had done a lot of research. Hannah has described her first three months as a mom to be “blissful” and she will always feel blessed to have had such a serene birthing experience. Tyler said the couple feel lucky that their friend was there to capture the moment on camera.  He added: Its really special that we have those pictures. They captured the moment so perfectly. Hannah said: “The sun was out and it was beautul. I felt extremely powerful. “A few days afterwards he was checked out and everything was great. “I think all people should follow their hearts. I did what I thought was the best thing for my baby. “An unhindered birth allowed the experience to be sacred and it was incredible. I have never felt so connected to my body. I felt very blessed. “He’s so wonderful. I underestimated my capacity for love.”

The sisters, who had been living in the US for two to three years, were found dead on the banks of New Yorks Hudson River last October.Their bodies were discovered tied together at the waist and lying in an area where you would essentially walk right into the water.Now, it has emerged that they died by drowning.In a statement released yesterday, New York Chief Medical Examiner Dr Barbara Sampson also said the siblings had committed suicide.  “Today, my office determined that the death of the Farea sisters was the result of suicide, in which the young women bound themselves together before descending into the Hudson River, she said.Dr Sampson added that Rotana and Tala were among around  known suicides across the city in , according to PEOPLE. The sisters had been living roughly  miles away, in Virginia, and were wearing similar clothing when they entered the Hudson.As well as black leggings and fur-trimmed jackets, they were found bound together with duct tape, a press conference heard last year.  New York Police Department Chief of Detectives Dermot Shea said they were tied at the waist in a way that was keeping them together.But he said the tape wasnt meant to restrain them, CNN reports.The siblings were said to have likely entered the water alive. Their bodies were discovered by a horried passerby on October .Officials initially believed the pair may have committed suicide by leaping off George Washington Bridge, near the scene.But they were found to have no signs of trauma that would suggest such a fall - and experts later concluded they had drowned.  Sources in Virginia told detectives the sisters would rather inflict harm on themselves and commit suicide thanto Saudi Arabia. Detectives used eyewitness testimonies, video evidence and the eldest sisters credit card purchases for food, hotel and transportation to determine that there was likely no foul play involved in the deaths. The two had been last seen by family in Virginia in November . They subsequently stayed at a shelter facility for domestic violence victims until the end of August, according to reports.   They apparently arrived in New York City on September  before staying at a number of high-end hotels, Det Shea said. According to police, Rotana and Tala had allegedly been subjected to physical abuse and may have applied for US asylum. A Saudi official denied claims that the country ordered the sisters and their mum, who lives in the US, tothere.If you need to speak to someone, Samaritans are available   by calling   or by emailing jo@samaritans.org

story: NewsMum asks woman to donate breast milk to her son - but things take a weird turnA woman has shared screen shots of a bizarre conversation she had with a fellow mum about breast milkShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  JAN NewsA conversation about breast milk took a bizarre turn"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen it comes to feeding a newborn, some parents opt to use breast milk and others dont. Those who chose breast milk can be faced with several issues - especiallythey struggle to produce their own. Thankfully the internet has a solution for this. For years generous women have been offering up their spare breast milk for babies in need via social media and websites. But while this act of kindness may bring about joy, it can sometimes also be a bit bizarre. One unnamed woman recently saw the darker side of her charitable actions, after a mum contacted her to ask for some of her milk.  The conversation between the two began civilly, as the mum messaged the woman to askshe could donate some milk to her. In screen shots of their chat shared on Imgur, we can see that the woman is more than willing to give away her milk, she responds asking how old the little one is and asks how much she requires. The mum reveals that her son is almost two-years-old and eats a lot. She subsequently offers to take it all off the womans hands.  The woman, who has her own six-week-old daughter, says she can spare about  ounces of milk for her fellow parent. I can spare about  ounces todayyou can pick up. My girl is only six weeks old so Im reserving most of the milk for a baby her age or any preemies in need in the Facebook group. However the other mum isnt impressed by her offer and asks for more. She replied: Lol... ounces  He eats like almost  a day. Thats only like  days worth. [Friends name] said you make tonnes of milk so I was hoping you could give a bit more. Hes got a sensitive stomach and breast milk is one of the few things his little tummy can handle.  He was a preemie too. The woman remains levelheaded with her reply and kindly tells the mum shell see how much she has left over after the rest has been claimed as shes donating with the intention of helping out an infant preemie. Her answer adds fuel to the fire and outraged the mum sends off another message. It reads: Dont understand why you cant just give it to me  Why does it have to be a preemie My boy was a preemie and he is a baby in need.   The woman stands her ground, reminding the mum that her son is no longer a baby and doesnt actually need any breast milk. No offence but your kid is a toddler, not a baby who needs exclusive breast milk. Ive offered you what I can spare already and am happy to see how much I have left over after donating the majority this weekend, she said. Im happy to send you a message to let you know. Realising shes not going to get what she wants, the mum decides to turn nasty and lashes out. The conversation ends with her writing: Whatever b****, keep your sour milk. Its probably tainted with booze and painkillers. Feel sorry for whichever poor kid ends up with it.

title: inside worlds spookiest abandoned places
story: NewsInside the worlds spookiest abandoned places - from decaying theme parks to empty spa townsHaunting photos have captured places all around the world which havent seen humans for yearsShareCommentsByMatt Roper:,  JAN NewsThe development of  Disney-like houses stands empty "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAmazing images have emerged of a Disney-like village filled with hundreds of identical fairytale castles - and zero residents. The eerie development of  faux-gothic villas in northern Turkey was built in an attempt to attract Arab buyers. But only  of the homes were sold, and after Turkey’s economy collapsed, the place was abandoned. It’s not the only abandoned place which is as fascinating as it is spooky.From the crumbling buildings that once served as a Soviet-era spa resort to the abandoned and overground theme park in Japan which was once expected to rival Disneyland, Mirror takes a look at some of the best.  Haunting photos revealed a once-thriving spa town famous for is thermal springs abandoned and in ruins.The waters of immortality bubbling up from the ground in Tskaltubo, in west-central Georgia, were believed to possess healing properties for more than a thousand years. One bathing house in the town was even built exclusively for Joseph Stalin. But after the USSR collapsed in the early s, the stream of socialist visitors started to dry up and the once grand buildings were left to be reclaimed by time and nature.  Eerie images taken by photographer Roman Robroek show deserted arcades with columns topped by crumbling turquoise arches - that open onto balconies with views of the woods beyond.And wide stone staircases spiral down to the now empty bathing pools, where the ceramic tiles barely cling to the walls. Nara Dreamland, Japan Fascinating images recently captured the inside of an abandoned and overground theme park in Japan which was once expected to rival Disneyland. Nara Dreamland was built in , complete with fairytale castles, rollercoasters and other attractions. But the park struggled to compete when both Disney and Universal Studios opened up their own parts in nearby Osaka and Tokyo. The park was eventually closed in the summer of , but its attractions were left in place for over  years to rust and decay.  Photos revealed eerily quiet walkways, rollercoaster tracks choked by wild overgrowth, paint peeling off shabby attractions and twisted, rust metal where majestic water fountains once stood. After it closed it became a popular place for ‘haikyoists’ - a Japanese word meaning urban explorers, particularly those interested in ruined structures and landscapes. Houtouwan, China  Built on the steep hills of Shengshan Island, , fishermen once plied their trade in the village of Houtouwan in China. But thousands of inhabitants moved from the island, one of  islands on the Shengsi archipelago, in the early s, seeking better education, jobs and healthcare. They left only a small handful of residents still living there, and today even that group has dwindled to almost nobody.  Last year stunning pictures emerged from the village showing how it is being reclaimed by nature. Empty homes and other buildings in the once bustling community are now covered in green with some almost disappearing into the hills. Pripyat, Ukraine After the Chernobyl nuclear disaster in  tens of thousands were evacuated from neighbouring Pripyat, a city of ,. Fteen primary schools, a large hospital complex,  stores,  gyms, along with parks, cinemas, factories, pool, amusement park, and other marks of a thriving community. And it was all abandoned in just three hours when residents were told to leave.  Over three decades later, the ghost town is a freeze-frame of the Soviet Union in . Communist propaganda still hangs on walls, the hammer and sickle decorate lampposts awaiting May Day celebrations that never took place, and residents’ personal belongings litter the streets and abandoned buildings.  All clocks are frozen at :, the moment the electricity was cut. The place is also overrun with wild animals, while the only humans who visit are urban explorers who pay to go on guided tours to some of the city’s abandoned structures, including people’s flats and a fairground complete with ferris wheel which never opened. Cold war bunker, Dundee During the Cold War, underground monitoring stations were manned by members of the Royal Observer Corpsand one of their main purposes was to give the dreaded “four minute warning” in the case of a nuclear attack. But after the Soviet Union fell in  the bunkers were sealed shut or demolished.One near Dundee, however, was preserved exactly how it was when it was last entered at least  years ago.  Explorers who recently entered the secret site for the first time found old pots and pans, mugs, and washing up liquid alongside official Cold War communications technology. The bunker, built ft under the ground, and housed two people when it was operational, still has the original desk, cabinets and bunk beds that would have been used by volunteers. Blankets were filmed rotting on the bunk bed exactly where they had been left decades ago, and there is even a candle holder with the remains of a burned-out candle stuck in the base. Ferrybridge Power Station, Wakefield Millions of people who travel up the M motorway in West Yorkshire will be familiar with Ferrybridge power station’s huge towers. But few except the men and women who once worked there have ever seen inside one of Britain’s tallest buildings. The giant towers have been abandoned since March  when the film that owns Ferrybridge closed up shop, has now applied for permission from Wakefield Council to knock it down. Photographer Paul Crumpton managed to get inside the huge structure, taking impressive pictures of the machinery and once-bustling control rooms which now lie stationary and abandoned. He found vast control , workspaces and equipment as well as dusty and rusting pipes, tanks and turbines.

title: dundee suited her and she suited it tributes to mcmanus registrar sally mcintosh 47
story: Tributes have been paid to popular McManus galleries and museum registrar Sally McIntosh, who has died following a short illness aged .Sally had worked at the museum since , having first come to the city as a student in the s.Paying tribute, her brother-in-law Paul Thomson said: “She was extremely funny and had a very dry sense of humour.“She was really into music, particularly American indie bands. She spent a lot of time going to gigs and festivals.“She worked for a little while at Waterstones in Dundee which was ideal for her. She was very much into reading about Scottish history, as well as jewellery, art and design.“She also loved to travel. She went to Japan and the US and a number of countries around Europe.” vw, px"   vw, px"  Sally first came to Dundee in  to study for her Honours degree in jewellery and metalwork at Dundee University.As an artist, Sally was once commissioned to create a le-sized wire mannequin for Italian fashion label Moschino.Finishing her degree in , she moved to Aberdeen and worked for a time at both Robert Gordon University and Aberdeen University libraries.She then went to St Andrews University to complete a postgraduate diploma in museum and gallery studies, before working at Aberdeen Art Gallery where her role included managing the collections and travelling with items.Paul said that Sally was a very inclusive and caring woman. If there was a big group of people, Sally would make sure everyone felt included, so much so that at a joint th birthday party held for him and Sally’s sister Robin, she spent most of the night chatting to a table of youngsters.Paul added: “She spent all the time with them, chatting and making sure they were enjoying themselves.“She was always trying to make sure people were included.”Paul praised Sally as a helpful, thoughtful, talented, smart and supportive woman.He added: “She was really happy in Dundee. It suited her and she suited Dundee.“She loved the people she worked with and she loved the job that she was doing.”Gareth Jackson-Hunt, museum service section leader at Leisure and Culture Dundee, said: “Sally loved working in museums and Dundee museums and art galleries offered a new opportunity to work with a ied and large collection.“Sally fitted into the team well with her sense of humour and no-nonsense attitude.“She was a valued member of the team, friend and colleague and will be sadly missed by all who she worked with.”Sally was also a devoted fan of the TV show Outlander and a prominent member of fan group Outlandish UK.Lisa Lyall from Outlandish UK said: “Sally was one of the early members of the group which became official in January .“We grew quickly and we asked her to come on board to help manage the running of the group and to help us organise our next big event which at that time was the Outlandish UK Gathering in Crieff in .“Her creatively and enthusiasm shone through and helped us bring a very special event to more than  people from all over the world. We will miss her greatly but she will always be a part of us.”A celebration of Sally’s le will be held at Baldarroch Crematorium, Crathes, tomorrow at .pm.Those attending are asked to wear purple, which was her favourite colour.Because of Sally’s love for dogs, donations will be collected for Guide Dogs Scotland and Macmillan nurses who looked after her while she was unwell.

title: dundee uniteds sam stanton does not want to experience another scottish cup shock
story: Sam Stanton has been on both ends of cup shocks in his time, and it’s the feeling when he was on the wrong end of one that makes him determined to make sure Dundee United win their fourth-round tie against Montrose.As a Hibs player, Stanton was part of the side that made an unexpected exit at the hands of Raith Rovers.That painful memory is one he does not want to experience again.“I’ve actually had good and bad in the cup and, hopefully, this can be another good memory,” said the midfielder.“When I was at Dumbarton, we had a couple of games where we weren’t expected to win and did, so that was a nice feeling.“But, when I was at Hibs, we were beaten by Raith and that definitely wasn’t a nice experience.“They were in the Championship and we were in the Premier League, so everyone expected us to get through. It wasn’t good when we lost.“That feeling is one you don’t want again and results like that one just show you can’t take anything for granted.“Teams in Scotland in all the leagues have good players and,you don’t have the proper approach, you will have problems.”And Stanton expects Montrose to battle tooth and nail to cause a shock tomorrow but believes United will be ready to cope with that.“These are dficult games because you know one team is giving everything they can to beat you because they have that nothing-to-lose mentality about them.“I’ve been there myself in those cup-ties when I was with Dumbarton, where you play teams who are bigger than your club and you don’t normally play against.“It excites you and it’s a chance for you to show how good you are. It’s why,you’re the bigger team, you can never take these games for granted.”He believes the key to avoiding a shock is treating the opposition with the respect they deserve and working towards the tie asit was a big game.“We have prepared for this one like we do every other game and that makes sure you have the right attitude.“The manager has had his videos of Montrose and been telling us about their strengths and weaknesses.“That way you make sure you are going into the game with the right mentality.”And,promotion from the Championship this term is by far the No  goal, Stanton admits he would love to go as far as possible in the cup.“A cup run is always important for the supporters and we know that.“For the players as well, it’s nice to do well and, as a football club, it is always important that we go as far as we can in the cup.“It’s another game we want to win and,you can string some wins together in the league and add a cup run to that as well, it’s always a help.”Stanton is also well aware that a side story tomorrow will be Tangerines legend Sean Dillon coming up against them for the first time since he ended a -year stay at Tannadice in .He expects the man who won the cup with United in  to get a rousing welcome from Arabs but, once that is out of the way and the game kicks off, it will be business as usual.“Sean left before I arrived at United but I know what a good player he was for the club.“He was here a long time and I’m sure he will get a good reception from our fans who travel up there.“For us, it’s about making sure he’s not the one getting clapped off the pitch after the game has finished.”

title: jim mcintyre relieved as dundee remain in scottish cup
story: Dundee boss Jim McIntyre was relieved to still be in the Scottish Cup after his side scraped a draw with Queen of the South at Dens Park.Saturday’s fourth-round clash saw the Doonhamers deservedly move ahead through veteran striker Stephen Dobbie’s rd goal of the campaign.Although Jesse Curran struck a fine equaliser at the end of the first half, it was to prove the Dark Blues only shot on target over the  minutes.It was down to the heroics of debut keeper Seny Dieng, on loan from QPR for the rest of the season, that McIntyre’s men can look forward to a replay at Palmerston next week.And Jim conceded they were outplayed for much of the  minutes by the visitors.However, on a day of shock results that saw Motherwell and Ayr United go down to lower level opposition, Aberdeen held at home by Stenhousemuir and St Mirren having to battle back from two goals down against Alloa to edge through, being in the hat for the fth-round draw was a consolation.It will see Dundee face the Dons or Stenny away –they can come through the second game.“I thought Queen of the South were better than us. We didn’t start the game well,” said Jim.“These cup games are always dficult. Just look at the results around the other clubs and there’s been a few shocks.“I’m just glad that we’re still in the cup and we have another chance to recty that performance. We all know it was short of what we’re looking for.”If he was unhappy with his team’s work, the manager did stress the quality Queens showed did not surprise him.“You’ve got to credit Queen of the South. Give them a bit of credit, they played well.“You know what it’s like when a Championship or lower team comes to a Premiership club. You know they are going to be right up for the game and you know you are going to be in a fight.“They beat Ross County - last week which was a fabulous result against a team who’ve just knocked Motherwell out.”On top of getting another chance, Jim was pleased with the debuts he handed to Dieng, Craig Curran and second-half subs Andy Dales and Andrew Nelson.“The positives for me were the introduction of the newer players who all contributed and there will be better days ahead for us.”

title: jim mclean saddened by the waygoing of tannadice legends
story: It’s always sad when a football legend moves on from a club.However, that is the nature of the game, and spaces have to be freed up for new talent brought in or coming through.I can remember a couple of Dundee United-supporting friends being upset when Andy Rolland left the club.They felt, at that time, he could still do a good job for the team.Signed from Cowdenbeath in , Rolland, nicknamed “The Galloping Major”, would stay for  years at Tannadice.United wanted him to stay on but the player had an offer from American club Fort Lauderdale Strikers.Given his tremendous service in playing well over  games for the Terrors, the club immediately granted him a free transfer in September .He said at the time: “This offer has come right out of the blue.“Fort Lauderdale phoned me on Thursday, wanted me to travel on Saturday, and then play my first game for them on Sunday.“But that was too rushed for me.“I expect to go sometime next week.”He continued: “It’s a great offer, and I had to accept.“However, it’s a wrench leaving United after all these years.“Fort Lauderdale have offered me a -month all-year contract, but I’d rather come home when the main season finishes.”Tannadice manager Jim McLean was sorry to see his full-back go.“We will miss him – off the field as well as on it,” he said.“Since I’ve come into Tannadice, we have now lost three great long-serving players – Dennis Gillespie and Doug Smith being the others.“All of them were outstanding club men, and great examples for our young players.”The Dundee United directors also showed their appreciation of his loyalty by making a special payment to him in lieu of a benefit.On ing from America, where he also turned out for Los Angeles Aztecs, Rolland spent two years with Harry Melrose’s Dunfermline, before ending his playing career back at Cowdenbeath.He also managed the Central Park side for a spell.

title: no excuses from nathan ralph for dundees poor cup display
story: If excuses were his thing, full-back Nathan Ralph wouldn’t be short of a few to explain Dundee’s below-par display as they were held at home by second-tier Queen of the South in the Scottish Cup on Saturday.After the three-week winter break, the Dark Blues were not alone in looking rusty as they faced up to the Doonhamers at Dens Park.Elsewhere, as other Premiership outfits got back to competitive action for the first time since the turn of the year, the fourth round saw Motherwell crash out at home to Ross County and Aberdeen held by minnows Stenhousemuir.Dundee were also facing a team that has been in fine form of late and who, in veteran Stephen Dobbie, can boast one of the best strikers in the country, not just the Championship.That they came to Dens and turned in a high level of performance should have come as no surprise.Last, and certainly not least, what turned out to be the first leg of this tricky tie saw Dundee hand debuts to no fewer than four players in the shape of goalkeeper Seny Dieng and attackers Craig Curran, Andy Dales and Andrew Nelson.With so many new faces involved, it was perhaps understandable the home team’s play at times lacked cohesion, though ironically at the weekend it was generally speaking the new players who were the pick of the bunch.That’s all the get-outs listed and Ralph isn’t too interested in any of them. For him, the bottom line is Dundee should have been better than this.“It was very frustrating on Saturday. I think our performance first half, we should be thankful we are still in the cup really,” he said.“It wasn’t good enough. They’ve got the goal to go ahead and then Jesse has done brilliantly just before half-time to get it back and have us level.“It was a good time for us to score and then we did definitely play better in the second half. On the whole, though, it was not good enough.“I suppose it does happen in the cup, we saw that with some of the other results, and the big thing is we are still in there and have a replay where we can make it into the next round.“So we maybe shouldn’t be too hard on ourselves over it but we’re still not happy with the performance.”Like most players after a bad game, now the -year-old just wants to get out on a pitch again and try to put things right.That’s why he breathed a sigh of relief on Sunday when Hearts’ televised clash with Livingston produced a result.Had the Jambos not edged past the Lions, a replay would have been tonight and Dundee’s Premiership visit to Tynecastle would have been postponed.“We have another game right away and that’s good. The one thing we didn’t want was no game this week because Hearts had drawn their cup-tie.“The thing you want to do after the winter break is get back into playing regularly again right away and you don’t want to be missing games because of things like that. You want to get points on the board as soon as possible.”Turning to the subject of the new arrivals, Ralph believes they will signicantly boost the chances of top-flight survival.So far, he’s been impressed by what he’s seen.He added: “I thought the new lads looked sharp and direct. They definitely want to get on the ball, create and make things happen.“I think them coming in this month will be good for the squad and they are going to help us going forward.”
